title: Messi in Mexico : The missed opportunity of Inter Miami letdown in Monterrey

CF Monterreyâ€™s Estadio BBVA is one of the crown jewels of North American soccer. Tucked into a valley in the Sierra Madre Oriental mountain range, it is a futuristic, metal-and-concrete venue with brutalist touches. Like a spaceship thatâ€™s come to earth, the place is wrapped in shimmering aluminum over a steel substructure, something thatâ€™s led locals to refer to it as El Gigante de Acero â€” the steel giant.

Climb high enough in the stadiumâ€™s upper bowl and the venueâ€™s most distinct feature comes into view. Cerro de la Silla is a nearly 6,000-foot mountain whose peak looms large over the opening in the stadiumâ€™s roof, offering one of the most scenic views in global football. During matches in the late afternoon, the sun filters through translucent sections of the stadium and casts playful shadows on the pitch.
The World Cup last came here in 1986 and the shadows cast across the field in Monterrey harken back to the imagery surrounding that tournament: Argentine legend Diego Maradona sprinting across sun and shade, in one short stretch scoring arguably the greatest goal in the history of the World Cup and also providing its most infamous moment. Maradona left that tournament a hero, carried off on the shoulders of his teammates after winning it all. The World Cup will return here in 2026, 40 years on from that fateful moment.
Tonight, Maradonaâ€™s Argentine heir has come to Mexico. Lionel Messi and Inter Miami are visiting BBVA to finish a CONCACAF Champions Cup quarterfinal against Monterrey. The stakes are lower for Messi than they were for Maradona, with the 36-year-old having already won all the biggest trophies for club and country. But there is still tremendous intrigue surrounding this match, Messiâ€™s first and maybe last-ever competitive game in Mexico.
Messi does not enjoy the sort of adulation in Mexico that he does elsewhere in the world. The country has its own sporting legends and Messiâ€™s presence has been so scarce here that few have formed any real attachment to him. Tonight, itâ€™s apparent that the Argentine wonâ€™t enjoy the effusive treatment heâ€™s received in road matches in Major League Soccer. There are very few Messi jerseys in the crowd and when his name is announced in the starting lineup, the boos are deafening. Theyâ€™re topped only by jeers hurled at Miami coach Tata Martino, who made himself persona non-grata in Mexico after leading the menâ€™s national team to a group-stage elimination at the 2022 World Cup.

Even so, Messi and the rest of Miamiâ€™s star-studded lineup have visions of grandeur. Down 2-1 after the first leg in South Florida, theyâ€™ve come to one of the most fearsome venues in Mexican soccer hellbent on doing what few MLS sides have done: win a knockout series in Mexico.

That competitive fire has been stoked in recent days by a dustup in the tieâ€™s opening leg; one which saw Martino, Messi, Luis Suarez and Jordi Alba engaged in a shouting match with Monterreyâ€™s coaching staff outside of the locker room. The interaction has created a feeding frenzy in the press and has given the match an even bigger feel.
The crowd here in Monterrey is pulsing and full of energy. Pyrotechnics ignite as both teams take the pitch. Miamiâ€™s young and inexperienced bench looks doe-eyed as they arrive in the dugout. The noise and fury of the place is like nothing theyâ€™ve seen in MLS.

The night before, the Columbus Crew shocked Liga MX powerhouse Tigres in a shootout victory at Estadio Universitario, just across town. Miamiâ€™s dreams of a comeback, though, evaporate about a half an hour into the match, when a goalkeeping gaffe hands Monterrey the opening goal and puts Miami down by two on aggregate. Things go from bad to worse early in the second half when Monterrey gets another. By the end, Miami is humiliated, with Messi openly expressing his frustration at his teammates. Alba isnâ€™t even around to get yelled at â€” he was sent off late in the match after losing his cool at an opponent.
In the end, Messi and Miamiâ€™s quest to make noise in Monterrey ends with a whimper. The Argentine and his teammates walk off the field while 50,000 fans belt out a NorteÃ±o â€” the traditional music of the region â€” in celebration. The squandered opportunity is a huge loss for Miami and maybe an even bigger one for MLS. Gone is the opportunity for the highest-profile team in MLS history to claim continental glory. Gone is this particular opportunity for Miami to play against the worldâ€™s best at the Club World Cup next year, the prize afforded by continental dominance.
And gone is Lionel Messi from Mexico, ferried away on a bus, not on his teammateâ€™s shoulders.

Inter Miamiâ€™s hotel in Monterrey is an ornate, five-star facility tucked away in the heart of the cityâ€™s fashion district, its equivalent to Rodeo Drive. The hotel has been fully barricaded in anticipation of Messiâ€™s arrival and is guarded by about a dozen police, many decked out in riot gear. On Tuesday, a day before Miamiâ€™s encounter with Los Rayados, wealthy shoppers, students from the local private high school and corporate types all mingle in the mid-afternoon haze.
The cops may have been needed the day before, when Miami arrived at the hotel to find hundreds of shrieking fans eager to get a peek at Messi and friends. Things are much calmer today, with about 20 curiosity seekers lined up around the hotelâ€™s perimeter. Their interest is piqued when a tour bus rumbles by, presumably carrying Miamiâ€™s players. Their excitement is quelled when they realize itâ€™s the Columbus Crew delegation, which is staying at an adjacent facility. Mixed in with the crowd is a floppy-haired seven-year-old named Elian. Heâ€™s decked out in Argentinaâ€™s signature baby blue and white with Messiâ€™s name and the numbers peeling off his back. Elian is accompanied by his uncle, who brought him here from Tijuana, some 1,500 miles away. He looks down and shifts nervously.
Is Monterrey his favorite team? Elian shakes his head sheepishly. No. Itâ€™s not Club Tijuana, either â€” his favorite team is Argentina. All he wants tonight, he says, is a photo with Messi.
At the moment, the Argentine is watching Wednesday afternoonâ€™s Champions League encounter between Paris Saint Germain and Barcelona â€“ the only two professional clubs Messi ever knew before he arrived in Miami, both of which squandered their relationships with the Argentine. At Barcelona, financial troubles led to a forced exile, one Messi still resents to this day. Things never went all that well at PSG, where Messi struggled to adapt to life in Paris and clashed with club leadership before leaving for MLS.
Before heâ€™d even played a minute for Miami, though, club owners David Beckham and Jorge Mas believed they had already struck gold. Pre-Messi, Inter Miami was a bottom-of-the-table club. The franchise had sputtered out of the gate in 2020, losing games and credibility.
â€œIs it good enough? No, we want to succeed on the field. We want to win trophies. Thatâ€™s the most important thing,â€ said Beckham said during a roundtable discussion with a group of reporters last July, three days before Messiâ€™s debut. â€œWe do feel that weâ€™ve succeeded, but short-term success, we have Lionel Messi. Thatâ€™s success.â€

With Messi on board, Miamiâ€™s win-loss record became a secondary narrative; the Fort Lauderdale-based club had become the most talked-about brand in the world. The financial returns of Messiâ€™s presence in MLS are also already evident. His Inter Miami jersey is among the highest-selling in the world, and today, outside of the hotel, almost everybody waiting to get a peek at the Argentine is sporting one, and often the newest version with the clubâ€™s new front-of-shirt sponsor, Royal Caribbean cruise lines.
Among them is Carlos, a 25-year-old who lives two hours away in Chiapas. He brought along a pair of friends. The trio paid three times the price of a regular match ticket, roughly $550, to see Messi live for the first time.
â€œYes, of course (I have his shirt,)â€ he says as a police officer keeps watch behind him. â€œI have their home jersey and Iâ€™m going to buy the black one, too. Even after Messi leaves (MLS) Iâ€™ll keep watching. I subscribed for the MLS Season Pass because of him.â€
In many ways, Carlos is MLSâ€™s dream consumer, the type of international fan MLS has struggled to attract. And Messiâ€™s presence in MLS has led to a sizable influx of attention from abroad.
Thereâ€™s a narrative right now, on social media especially, that Mexican soccer is in a downturn. Mexicoâ€™s national team has struggled to compete with the U.S. men for a stretch and Liga MX has tightened its ties with MLS in recent years, seeking financial gain. The two leagues are partners in Leagues Cup, their annual midseason tournament that pits every one of MLS and Liga MXâ€™s clubs against each other. Itâ€™s a controversial tournament in Mexico, due at least in part to the fact that all the games take place in the United States.

Boosters will frequently tout MLSâ€™s growth from a business perspective, saying that other leagues around the world have begun to study its business model. Some MLS fans care about this sort of news, but a much larger segment measures the leagueâ€™s growth by looking at how it does in meaningful competition against other teams in the region, particularly Mexican teams.
MLS seemed to be making inroads in 2022 when it finally won the CONCACAF Champions League, the predecessor to the Champions Cup. But the broader picture is still fairly bleak. Just in this yearâ€™s knockout round, Inter Miami, the Philadelphia Union and the New England Revolution were outscored by their Mexican opponents by a combined total of 20-4.

The Crewâ€™s victory did manage to break the crust of apathy that exists towards MLS amongst Liga MX fans. They won in Mexico and did something even rarer, play attractive football. The Mexican press took note, with some wondering whether MLS was finally making significant inroads in terms of quality.
That lasted less than 24 hours. In the later stages of Wednesday nightâ€™s encounter between Miami and Monterrey, two reporters offered their own evaluation of MLSâ€™ quality as Messi and Co. struggled.

He makes it clear that thereâ€™s little excuse for Miamiâ€™s performance on Wednesday, mentioning that the Columbus Crew managed a result against Tigres just across town a night prior. But he canâ€™t help but mirror Martino.
â€œI think if you compare our bench to Monterreyâ€™s, you get a pretty good picture of what itâ€™s like,â€ he said. â€œI hope that MLS will take the right steps to potentially, in the future, be able to have a deeper roster so that you can compare a little bit more and you can kind of make a push for this competition more.â€
Inter Miamiâ€™s elimination wonâ€™t drastically change how MLS operates. But on Wednesday, it was evident how frustrated Messi was with the lack of quality from his Inter Miami teammates. That shouldnâ€™t be taken lightly. If Messi has considered extending his contract with Inter Miami beyond 2025, being stuck on a struggling team thatâ€™s hamstrung by MLS roster rules could make him reconsider.

â€œI think (MLS) has every opportunity to (grow),â€ Messi told ESPN after his introductory press conference last August. â€œThat growth depends a lot on the league. Itâ€™s an ideal time to grow.
